sections.name: Python Basics
sections.description: An introduction to fundamental coding concepts of programming in Python.

units.name: Variables and Data Types
units.description: Understanding how to use variables and different data types in Python.

tasks.name: Documetation
tasks.description: Student can demonstrate writing effective comments in code and using self-documenting naming conventions.
tasks.genprompt: Generate multiple-choice questions. Each question has four answers. Write them in the question object format. The content of the question is about writing effective comments in Python code and using self-documenting naming conventions. Focus on documentation practices, naming strategies, and how comments help programmers understand code.

questions.prompt: Text in the program that is meant for programmers to read and ignored by the program itself.
A way of writing identifiers without using spaces that is easily readable.
A set of common rules that programmers share to help each other understand one another's code.
A way of naming objects in code that is easy for humans to read.
Why might a programmer include a comment above a complex calculation in their code?
questions.correctAnswer: To explain the purpose or logic of the calculation
answers: To explain the purpose or logic of the calculation
To make the program run faster
To change the syntax of the code
To store values for later use

questions.prompt: Which of these is an example of a self-documenting variable name?
If a variable is named 'temp', what is a better self-documenting alternative if it stores a user's age?
What is the main benefit of using self-documenting names instead of comments for simple values?
questions.correctAnswer: It reduces the need for extra comments and makes code easier to read
answers: It makes the program run faster
It allows multiple programmers to edit at once
It reduces the need for extra comments and makes code easier to read

questions.prompt: Where is the best place to put a comment explaining a functionâ€™s purpose?
answers: Randomly in the middle of the code
After the closing brace of the function

questions.prompt: Which type of comment is most useful for reminding yourself or others of a TODO item in code?
questions.correctAnswer: Inline comment with a clear marker like TODO
answers: A multiline comment explaining every line
Inline comment with a clear marker like TODO
No comment is needed for TODO items
A comment at the end of the program

questions.prompt: Which symbol is used to create a single-line comment in Python?
How can you create a multi-line comment in Python?
questions.correctAnswer: Use triple quotes (''' or """) around the comment text
answers: Use multiple # symbols on each line
Use triple quotes (''' or """) around the comment text
Use // at the beginning and end of the block

tasks.name: Datatypes
tasks.description: Students can identify literal values where they appear, and differentiate between boolean, integer, float, and sting values.
tasks.genprompt: Generate multiple-choice questions. Each question has four answers. Write them in the question object format. The content of the question is about identifying and understanding different data types in Python, including boolean, integer, float, string, and character types. Focus on their definitions, examples, and how they are used in programming.

questions.prompt: A categorization of data that differentiates it from other data (numbers/letters/etc.).
A value that is a basic data type, and not a complex object.
A data type with a whole number, positive or negative.
A data type with a decimal place, positive or negative.
A data type with a 'True' or 'False' value.
A data type that is a single character, such as 'a' or '1'.
A datatype that contains one or more human-readable characters, always encapsulated in quotation marks.
A value that is written directly in the code, such as a number or string.
Changing a value of a certain data type to a different data type.
Which of the following is a literal integer value in Python?
Which of the following is a boolean literal?
What data type would the value 3.0 belong to?
What is the type of the literal 'Hello, world!'?
Which of the following values is a character literal in Python?
If you perform conversion on the integer 5 to a string, what will the new value look like?
Which literal would be stored in a variable declared as a float?
Which of the following is NOT a primitive datatype in Python?
How does Python treat the literal '0' in quotation marks?
Which of these is a valid boolean expression in Python?
What will be the datatype of the result when you divide 5 by 2 in Python 3?

tasks.name: Assignment
tasks.description: Students can store values into memory (variables) with a variety of assignment operators.
tasks.genprompt: Generate multiple-choice questions. Each question has four answers. Write them in the question object format. The content of the question is about storing values in memory using variables and assignment operators in Python. Focus on variable assignment, different types of assignment operators, and how they are used in programming.

questions.prompt: A value that is stored in memory and can be changed.
A name of a variable that can be used in expressions.
A piece of data that can be stored in a variable or used in an expression.
Replacing an expression, object or variable name with the associated value.
Associating a value with an identifier to create a variable or object.
A symbol in code used for assignment.
A value that is referring to a different value.
A value that is not changed after it is set.
Which assignment operator will add 2 to the current value of y and store the result back in y?
If you want to copy the value of variable a into variable b, which operator would you use?
What happens when you try to change a constant value in Python?
questions.correctAnswer: It will cause an error if reassignment is attempted
answers: It converts the constant to a variable
It will cause an error if reassignment is attempted

questions.prompt: Which of the following is an example of a referential assignment in Python?
What will be the value of x after this code? x = 10; x -= 4
Which of the following is a valid use of the multiplication assignment operator in Python?
Which of the following assignments will store a float value in variable x?
What is the difference between '=' and '==' in Python?
questions.correctAnswer: '=' assigns a value, '==' checks for equality
answers: '=' assigns a value, '==' checks for equality

questions.prompt: If you write x = y = 10 in Python, what is happening?
questions.correctAnswer: Both x and y are assigned the value 10
answers: x is assigned y's old value
y is assigned x's old value
Both x and y are assigned the value 10

questions.prompt: If you assign the value of one variable to another, what happens when the first variable changes later?
questions.correctAnswer: The second variable keeps its value unless explicitly reassigned
answers: The second variable automatically updates to match
The second variable keeps its value unless explicitly reassigned

questions.prompt: What happens if you try to assign a value to a variable that hasn't been declared in Python?
questions.correctAnswer: Python automatically creates the variable and assigns the value
answers: Python automatically creates the variable and assigns the value

tasks.name: Expressions
tasks.description: Students can write expressions that use substitution, comparisons, and arithmetic operators.
tasks.genprompt: Generate multiple-choice questions. Each question has four answers. Write them in the question object format. The content of the question is about writing expressions in Python that involve substitution and arithmetic operators. Focus on how expressions are formed, evaluated, and their role in programming. Do not generate questions about comparisons.

questions.prompt: A piece of code that completes a small task in the program.
An 'equation' in code that must be resolved before continuing the program by using substitution, comparisons, and arithmetic.
A symbol in code used to perform math equations in an expression.
What is the value of x after this code runs? x = 5; x = x + 3
What will be the value of x after this code? x = 2; x = x ** 3
What will be the value of x after this code runs? x = 7; x = x * 2
If x = 4 and y = 2, what is the value of x // y in Python?
What is the result of the expression 10 % 3 in Python?
If a = 6 and b = 4, what is the value of a - b * 2?
What is the result of the expression (5 + 3) * 2 in Python?
If x = 10 and y = 3, what is the value of x / y in Python?
What will be the value of z after this code? z = 15; z = z // 4
What is the result of the expression 2 ** 4 + 1 in Python?
What is the result of the expression 8 / 2 * 3 in Python?
What is the result of the expression 10 - 3 + 2 * 4 in Python?
In Python, which operator has the highest precedence: multiplication (*), addition (+), or parentheses ()?
When Python evaluates an expression with multiple operators of equal precedence, what rule does it follow?

units.name: Comparisons and Conditions
units.description: Understanding how to use variables and different data types in Python.

tasks.name: Comparisons and Conditions
tasks.description: Student can demonstrate how conditions resolve by using a boolean value or and expression using a comparsion operator.

questions.prompt: A symbol used to compare two values, such as 'greater than' or 'equal to'.
A statement that evaluates to True or False, often used in control flow.
A section of code that has been segregated and can only be run by some other part of the code.
A code block that is run when a given condition resolves as 'True' or 'not False'.
Putting one type of code block or value inside a similar code block or value.
The most common conditional statement that runs if the condition resolves as 'True' or 'not False'.
Very common conditional statement that runs if its condition is 'True' or 'not False' and the previous if statement's condition is 'False'.
Very common conditional statement that runs if all previous if and else if statements' conditions are 'False'.
What is the result of the expression: 7 > 3?
Which comparison operator checks if two values are NOT equal?
What will the condition (10 == 5) evaluate to?
Which keyword is used to add an alternative path with no condition when an 'if' condition is False?
What does the condition (x < 0) check for?
Which of these is a valid comparison operator?
What does an 'else if' (or 'elif') condition allow you to do?
questions.correctAnswer: Check another condition if the previous one is False
answers: Check another condition if the previous one is False

questions.prompt: What is the boolean result of (4 <= 4)?
Which of these conditions checks if x is both greater than 0 and less than 10?
In most programming languages, what value does a condition produce?
If (x == 10) is True, which branch will run in an if/else statement?
Which of these is an example of a logical error in conditions?
How many "if"s does an if statement have?
answers: One for each condition you want to check

questions.prompt: How many "else"s does an if statement have?
answers: One for each condition you want to check

questions.prompt: How many "elif"s does an if statement have?
questions.correctAnswer: One for each condition to check after the first
answers: One for each condition to check after the first
One for each condition you want to check
One for each "else" in the if statement

questions.prompt: "elif"s always goes...?
questions.correctAnswer: In between the if and else statements
answers: At the beginning of an if statement
At the end of an if statement
In between the if and else statements
At the beginning of an else statement

questions.prompt: An "else"s will never have a ...?

tasks.name: Conditional Loops
tasks.description: Student can demostrate the purpose of conditional loops.

questions.prompt: A code block that repeats for as long as a given condition resolves as 'True' or 'not False'.
A loop that continues until a condition is no longer True.
A loop that never ends because its condition always evaluates to True.
A loop inside another loop.
A keyword used to immediately end a loop, even if its condition is still True.
A keyword that skips the rest of the current loop iteration and continues with the next one.
In Python, which loop is generally used when the number of iterations is known ahead of time?
In Python, which loop is generally used when the number of iterations is not known and depends on a condition?
In Python, what will happen if a 'break' statement is executed inside a nested loop?
questions.correctAnswer: Only the current loop will terminate
answers: Only the current loop will terminate

questions.prompt: In Python, what will the 'continue' statement do inside a loop?
questions.correctAnswer: Skip the rest of the current iteration and continue with the next one
answers: Skip the rest of the current iteration and continue with the next one
Restart the loop from the first iteration

questions.prompt: Which of the following is an example of an infinite loop in Python?
In Python, what happens if the loop condition is false at the start of a 'while' loop?
questions.correctAnswer: The loop body will not execute
answers: The loop body will not execute

questions.prompt: Which of these statements is true about nested loops?
questions.correctAnswer: The inner loop completes all iterations for each iteration of the outer loop
answers: The inner loop completes all iterations for each iteration of the outer loop
The outer loop stops when the inner loop starts
Nested loops are only allowed with for loops
Break statements do not work inside nested loops

questions.prompt: Which statement will immediately exit a while loop regardless of the condition?
Which statement will skip the current iteration of a while loop and move to the next evaluation of the condition?
What is a common risk of using a while loop without modifying the variables involved in the condition?
If a while loop contains another while loop inside it, what is the correct term for this structure?
In Python, what happens if a while loop's condition never becomes False and there is no break statement?

tasks.name: Logical Operators
tasks.description: Students can demonstrate the use of logical operators to combine boolean expressions.

questions.prompt: An operator that combines two boolean expressions to return True if both are True.
An operator that combines two boolean expressions to return True if at least one is True.
An operator that negates a boolean expression.
What is the result of 'True and False'?
What is the result of 'True or False'?
What is the result of 'not True'?
Which logical operator is often used to check multiple conditions that all must be True?
Which logical operator is often used when only one of several conditions needs to be True?
Logical operators are used to combine or modify what type of values?
In Python, what does the expression '5 and 0' return?
In Python, what does the expression '0 or 10' return?
In Python, applying 'not' to a non-empty string like 'hello' will return:
In Python, what is the result of True + True?
In Python, what is the result of 5 * False?
In Python, what is the result of True * True?
In Python, what is the result of '[] or 5'?
In Python, what is the result of '{}' and 10?
In Python, what does the expression 'not []' evaluate to?
In Python, what is the result of '0 and 10'?
What is the result of 'None or "hello"' in Python?
In Python, what is the result of 'not ""'?
In Python, what is the result of '5 or 0'?
In Python, combining 'not True and False' evaluates to:
What is the result of 'not None or True' in Python?
In Python, what does the expression '[] and 100' return?

tasks.name: Error Messages
tasks.description: Student can use error messages to identify errors in their code, as well as differentiate between run-time, syntax, and logical errors.
tasks.genprompt: Generate multiple-choice questions. Each question has four answers. Write them in the question object format. The content of the question is about understanding different types of errors in Python, including run-time errors, syntax errors, and logical errors. Focus on how to identify these errors and their implications in programming.

questions.prompt: An error that occurs when the program is running, often due to invalid operations or data.
An error that occurs when the code does not follow the language's syntax rules.
An error that occurs when the code runs without crashing but produces incorrect results.
What type of error will occur if you try to divide a number by zero in Python?
What type of error is caused by missing a colon at the end of a Python if statement?
If a program calculates 2 + 2 and returns 5, what type of error is this?
What error type occurs if you try to add a number and a string in Python?
What kind of error would you see if you misspell a function name in your code?
What type of error occurs when parentheses are not properly closed in Python?
A program is supposed to calculate the area of a rectangle but accidentally multiplies length by 2 instead of length Ã— width. What error type is this?
What kind of error occurs if you forget the quotation marks around a string in Python?
What kind of error will Python produce for this line: x = (5 + 3
What type of error occurs if you forget to indent a line after a colon in Python?
If a program sorts a list but the output is in the wrong order due to a wrong comparison, what type of error is this?
What type of error occurs if you call a function with the wrong number of arguments?
What kind of error will Python produce if you write 'if x = 5:' instead of 'if x == 5:'?
A program is supposed to calculate the sum of numbers but uses subtraction instead. What type of error is this?
What type of error occurs if you try to concatenate a string with an integer without converting the integer?
What type of error occurs when a variable is used before it has been assigned a value?
What type of error occurs if you accidentally use the wrong operator in a calculation, producing incorrect results?

tasks.name: Debuggers
tasks.description: Student can use debugger stepping, watchpoints, and memory watchers to diagnose the operation of their code.

questions.prompt: A tool that can stop and step through a program to examine how it functions.
Using console output to quickly check data in the program while it runs.
Telling a debugger to run a statement without pausing.
Telling a debugger to break a statement or code block into smaller steps and step through them.
Telling a debugger to stop stepping through smaller parts of a statement or code block and continue to the next statement.
Telling a debugger to stop stepping through the program and run normally.
Marks a variable or object for tracking while debugging.
Marks a variable or object for tracking while debugging.
Tells a debugger to stop at a specified line of code.
Start the debugger if the program reaches this point.
A tool built into Python editors that helps pause and check code line by line.
Prints a value to the console without stopping the program.
Run one line of code but skip over any function details inside it.
Move inside a function call so you can see it run line by line.
Exit the current function and return to the line of code that called it.
Keeps the program running until another breakpoint is reached.
Stops when a chosen variableâ€™s value changes.
A marker in the code where the debugger will pause automatically.
Shows how the program moves from one line of code to the next.
The action of pausing the program at a set line to check values.
A command that continues running code until the next stop point.
When a debugger moves through code one line at a time.
Used to follow the changing value of a variable while paused.
Runs code until it enters a function, then lets you explore inside it.

tasks.name: Procedures
tasks.description: Students can write subroutines that have arguments/parameters and return values, and can substitute a procedure call with its return value.

questions.prompt: A repeatable code block that the program can jump to that can take arguments (inputs) and return values (outputs).
A partition of program memory that segregates different variables and objects.
The identifier of a value you can pass to a function to use it in that function's scope.
The value you passed to a function identified by its parameter name.
Ends a function, and if given a value, substitutes the function call with the value.
The value a function call is replaced with when the function reaches a return statement.
A function that does not include a return statement will return what by default in Python?
What is it called when you provide actual values to a function's parameters?
What keyword is used in Python to define a new function?
Which of these is an advantage of using functions in a program?
What is the name given to a variable defined inside a function, only accessible in that function?
What is the name given to a variable defined outside of any function, accessible throughout the program?
What happens if a function has multiple return statements?
questions.correctAnswer: The first return reached will end the function
answers: The first return reached will end the function
The last return always overrides the others

questions.prompt: What is the term for providing a default value to a parameter in a function definition?
Which of these is a correct way to call a function named 'greet' with one argument 'Alice'?
What is it called when a function calls itself?
What happens when a return statement is executed in a function?
questions.correctAnswer: The function stops and gives back a value
answers: The function stops and gives back a value

questions.prompt: How do you return multiple values in a return statement?
Given def greet(name, times=1): which call uses a keyword argument for 'name'?
Given def add(a, b): which call raises a TypeError for the wrong number of arguments?
Given def paint(color, size): which call uses only positional arguments?
In def show(*items): what does *items collect?
questions.correctAnswer: All extra positional arguments as a tuple
answers: All extra positional arguments as a tuple
All keyword arguments as a dict

questions.prompt: Given def area(w, h=2): which call correctly sets h to 3?
Given def power(base, exp=2): which call uses the default for exp?
Given def mix(a, b, c): which call sets a=3, b=1, c=2?
Given def draw(x, y): which call is invalid because a positional argument follows a keyword argument?
In def build(a, b=0, c=1): how many total parameters are defined?
Given def cook(temp, mode): which call raises a TypeError for giving multiple values for the same parameter?
Given def add(a,b): print(a+b); result = add(2,3); what is stored in result?
Given def f(): return 7; x = f() * 2; what is x?
Given def g(): return; y = g(); what is y?
Given def pair(): return 2, 3; t = pair(); which option best describes t?
answers: Two separate return values that can't be assigned

questions.prompt: Assume inc adds 1 to its input and dbl multiplies its input by 2; what is dbl(inc(3))?
When is the code inside a function executed?
answers: When the function is defined with def

questions.prompt: Which line correctly defines a function named hello that takes no parameters?
In a function, what is the main difference between return and print?
questions.correctAnswer: return sends a value back to the caller; print just displays text
answers: return sends a value back to the caller; print just displays text
return prints text; print sends a value back
print stops the function; return continues it

questions.prompt: Where should a function's docstring be placed?
questions.correctAnswer: As the first statement inside the function body
answers: As the first statement inside the function body
Above the def line in a comment
At the end of the file

questions.prompt: How many objects can a Python function return?
questions.correctAnswer: Exactly one object, but it can be a list
answers: Exactly one object, but it can be a list
Zero only; Python functions can't return

questions.prompt: Which naming style is recommended for function names in Python?

tasks.name: Ordered Collections
tasks.description: Student can create, add, remove, and sort elements in an array/list, and substitute specific element's values in an expression.

questions.prompt: A variable that holds multiple values in a specific sequence.
An unordered collection that has a series of values with their own identifying keys.
A single value stored inside a collection such as a list; accessed by its index..
The integer position used to locate an element in a list.
An index that counts from the end of a sequence.
A subsection of a sequence selected with [start:stop:step].
The number of elements contained in a collection.
A property meaning the object can be changed after creation.
In Python, an ordered, immutable collection of elements written with parentheses.
What Python structure is an ordered collection that is mutable and written with square brackets like [1,2,3]?
In nums=[10,20,30], the 1 in nums[1] is the ____.
In nums=[4,5,6,7], the -1 in nums[-1] is a ____.
The expression nums[1:4] uses a ____ to select a run of elements.
The value returned by len(nums) is the list's ____.
Changing nums[0]=99 shows that a Python list is ____.
A single value inside a list, such as 42 in [3,42,7], is an ____.
Which term names an ordered collection that is immutable and written with parentheses like (1,2,3)?
The phrase 'items keep their order and can be accessed by position' describes an ____.
The expression nums[::2] returns every other item using a ____ with a step.
In a list, what is the index of the first element?
What is the index of the last element in a list named items?
Given nums=[1,2,3]; nums.append([4,5]); what is nums?
Given nums=[1,2,3]; nums.extend([4,5]); what is len(nums)?
Given items=[10,20,30]; items.insert(1,15); what is items?
Given items=[2,4,6,8]; x=items.pop(); what are x and items?
What does the expression [3,1,4].sort() return?
Given nums=[5,1,5,2]; what does nums.count(5) return?
Given nums=[3,1,2]; nums.sort(); what is nums?
Given nums=[1,2]; nums += [3,4]; what is nums?
Given nums=[10,20,30]; 25 in nums evaluates to what?
Given nums=[1,2,3,4]; del nums[1]; what is nums?
Given nums=['b','a','c']; nums.reverse(); what is nums?

tasks.name: Iterative Loops
tasks.description: Students can use for..in/for..of loops to iterate through elements in an array/list or object/dictionary.

questions.prompt: A loop that runs a set number of times or over each item in a sequence using the 'for' keyword.
Any object you can loop over item by item in a for loop (examples: list, tuple, string).
One complete pass of the loop body for a single item or count.
The variable name that temporarily holds the current item during a for loop.
The process of visiting each element in a sequence one by one, usually with a loop.
The set of names available inside the loop body (e.g., the loop variable and variables defined before or within the loop).
A statement that immediately exits the nearest enclosing loop.
A statement that skips the rest of the current loop iteration and moves to the next one.
Which option loops over both index and value in nums=[10,20,30]?
What is the effect of break inside a for loop?
answers: Restarts the loop from the top

questions.prompt: What is the effect of continue inside a for loop?
questions.correctAnswer: Skips the rest of the current iteration
answers: Skips the rest of the current iteration

questions.prompt: How many times does for i in range(3): run the loop body?
Which option correctly traverses all characters in s='cat'?
Given nums=[1,2]; out=[]; for n in nums: out.append(n*2); what is out after the loop?
In nums=[10,20,30], what do i and v represent in for i, v in enumerate(nums):?
questions.correctAnswer: i is the index, v is the element value
answers: i is the index, v is the element value
i is the value, v is the next index
i and v are both values
i and v are both indexes

questions.prompt: What is printed by: for i in range(3): print(i)?
What is the value of total after: total=0; for i in range(4): total += i?
answers: Error: total needs to be a list

questions.prompt: What does this code print? for ch in 'dog': if ch=='o': break; print(ch)
What does this code print? for ch in 'cat': if ch=='a': continue; print(ch)
questions.correctAnswer: c t (each on its own line)
answers: c t (each on its own line)
c a t (each on its own line)

questions.prompt: What is the value of s after: s=''; for i in range(3): s += str(i)?

tasks.name: Nested Collections
tasks.description: Students can utilize multi-dimensional arrays, and store complex datatypes in arrays or objects.

questions.prompt: Providing multiple indices to find an element in a list that is itself an element in another list.

tasks.name: Unordered Collections
tasks.description: Student can create and retrieve values in a dictionary/map, and substitute specific element's values in an expression.

questions.prompt: A variable that holds many individual values in no particular order, because each value has its own key.
An unordered collection that has a series of values with their own identifying keys.
A word that represents a value in an unordered collection, or the value of a property.
Given d={'a':1,'b':2}; what does d['a'] evaluate to?
Given d={'x':1}; d['y']=3; what is d?
Which test checks whether 'id' is a key in d?
After d={'a':1}; d['a']=5; what is len(d)?
What happens when you access d['z'] and 'z' is not a key?
In {'a':1,'a':2}, what is the value of 'a'?
Which statement is true about dictionary keys?
questions.correctAnswer: Keys must be immutable types like str, int, or tuple
answers: Keys must be immutable types like str, int, or tuple
Keys must be unique only within values

questions.prompt: Given d={'0':'zero', 0:'number zero'}, what does d[0] return?
Given d={'a':1,'b':2}, what does d['a'] evaluate to?

tasks.name: Unordered Methods
tasks.description: Student can add, remove, and loop through key-value pairs in a dictionary/map.

questions.prompt: Given d={'k':9,'m':8}; del d['k']; what is d now?
Given d={'x':7}; what does len(d) evaluate to?
Which expression returns 0 if 'missing' is not a key in d?
answers: 0 if 'missing' not in d else d['missing']

questions.prompt: What does d.items() produce?
Which method returns a view of just the values in d?
Which method adds all key-value pairs from e into d, overwriting existing keys in d?
In for k in d:, what does k represent?
Which call removes key 'x' and returns its value, or 0 if 'x' is missing?
Which method returns a value you can loop over to get keys only?
Which method removes all key-value pairs from d?
Given a={'x':1}; b=a.copy(); a['x']=9; what is b['x']?
Which loop goes through both key and value?
answers: for v in d.values(), k in d.keys():

questions.prompt: Which loop iterates over both keys and values of d?
answers: for k in d.keys(), v in d.values():

questions.prompt: Which test checks if 'id' is a key in d?
Given d={'a':1}; what happens if you evaluate d['b'] when 'b' is not a key?
Which expression checks if key 'user' exists in d?
Given d={'x':1,'y':2}; which expression produces a list of keys?
Given d={'a':1,'b':2}; which one safely returns 0 when 'c' is not present?
Given d={'p':1}; e={'q':2}; which expression updates d with e in-place?
Given d={'b':2,'a':1}, what does sorted(d) return?
Given d={'a':1} and e={'b':2}, which creates a new merged dict without changing d or e (Python 3.9+)?
What does d.get('z') return when 'z' is not a key and no default is provided?
